revision.text:
The following is a [[glossary]] of common English language and scientific terms used in the description of [[gastropod]]s.
{{Compact ToC |c=C |i=I |j=J |k=K |l=L |v=V |x=X |y=Y |z=Z |seealso=yes |refs=yes |extlinks=yes }}
Acephalous. Headless.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Acinose. Full of small bulgings; resembling the kernel in a nut.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Aculeate. Very sharply pointed, as the teeth on the radula of some snails.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Acute. Sharp or pointed, as the [[Spire (mollusc)|spire]] of a shell, or the [[Lip (gastropod)|lip]] of a shell.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Acuminate. Long and tapering, as the spire of some shells.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Admedian. Next to the central object, as the lateral teeth on the lingual membrane.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Afferent. To bring in; when relating to a vessel or duct, indicating that it brings in its contents.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Amoeboid. Shaped like an amoeba, a small animalcule.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Amorphous. Without distinct form.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Amphibious. Inhabiting both land and water.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Amphidetic. With the ligament on both sides of the umbones.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Analogue. A likeness between two objects when otherwise they are totally different, as the wing of a bird and the wing of a butterfly.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Anastomosing. Coming together.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Annular. Made up of rings.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Anterior. The front or fore end.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Aquatic. Inhabiting the water.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Arborescent. Branching like a tree.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Arched. Bowed or bent in a curve.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Arcti-spiral. Tightly coiled, as some spiral shells.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Asphyxiating. Causing suspended animation; apparent death.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Assimilation. Act of converting one substance into another, as the changing of food-stuffs into living bodies.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Asymmetrical. Not symmetrical.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
[[Atrium (heart)|Atrium]].
Atrophied. Wasted away.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Attenuate. Long and slender, as in some shells.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Auditory. Connected with the hearing.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Auricled. Eared, or with ear-like appendages.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Basal. The bottom or lower part.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Biangulate. With two angles.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Bicuspid or bicuspidate. Having two cusps.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Bifid. Having two arms or prongs.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Bifurcated. Having two branches.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Bilateral. With two sides.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Bilobed. With two lobes.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
[[Blood sinus]].
Bulbous. Swollen.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Calcareous. Composed of carbonate of lime.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Callosity. A hardened and raised bunch, as the [[Callus (mollusc)|callus]] on the [[Columella (gastropod)|columella]] of some shells.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
[[Callus (mollusc)|Callus]]. A deposit of shelly matter.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Campanulate. Formed like a bell.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Canaliculate. Resembling a canal, as the deep [[Suture (gastropod)|sutures]] in some shells.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Cancellated. Formed of cross-bars, as the longitudinal and spiral lines which cross in some shells.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Cardiac pouch. Containing the heart and placed near the umb'ones of the shell.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Carinate. Keeled.<ref name="Baker 1898"/> With [[Keel (anatomy)|keel]].
Cartilaginous. Like cartilage.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Caudal. Tail-like, or with a tail-like appendage.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Cellular. Made up of cells.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Cerebral. Pertaining to the brain.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Channeled. Grooved or formed like a channel.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Chitinous. Formed of [[chitin]], as the [[radula]]s of gastropods.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Ciliary. By means of cilia.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Ciliated. Having cilia.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Cilium (plural cilia). A lash; used to designate the hairs on the mantle, gills, etc.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Clavate. Club-shaped.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Coarctate. Pressed together, narrowed.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Concave. Excavated, hollowed out.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
[[Conchiolin]].
Conic. Shaped like a cone.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Connective. A part connecting two other parts, as a muscle connecting two parts of the body, or a nerve connecting two ganglia.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Constricted. Narrowed.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Contractile. Capable of being contracted or drawn in, as the tentacle of a snail.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Convex. Bulged out, as the whorls of some snails.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Convoluted. Rolled together.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Cordate. Heart-shaped.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Corneous. Horn-like, as the [[Operculum (gastropod)|opercula]] of some gastropods.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Corrugated. Roughened by wrinkles.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Costate. Having rib-like ridges.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Crenulate. Wrinkled on the edges.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Crescentic. Like a crescent.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Cylindrical. Like a cylinder.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Decollated. Cut off, as the [[Apex (mollusc)|apex]] of some shells.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Decussated. With spiral and longitudinal lines intersecting, as the sculpture of some shells.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Deflexed. Bent downward, as the [[last whorl]] in some snails.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Dentate. With points or nodules resembling teeth, as the [[Aperture (mollusc)|aperture]] of some snails.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Denticulate. Finely dentate.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Depressed. Flattened, as the spire in some snails.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Dextral. Right-handed.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Digitiform. Finger-like.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Dilated. Expanded in all directions, as the aperture of a shell.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Dimorphism. With two forms or conditions.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
[[Dioecious]]. Having the sexes in two individuals, one male and one female.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Distal. The farthest part from an object.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Discoidal. Shaped like a flat disk.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Diverticulum. A pouch or hole, as the pouch containing the radula, or that containing the dart in helices.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Dormant. In a state of torpor or sleep.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Dorsal. The back. In gastropods the opposite to the aperture.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Ectocone. The outer cusp on the teeth of the radula.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Edentulous. Without teeth or folds, as the aperture in some gastropods.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Efferent. Carrying out.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Elliptical. With an oval form.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Elongated. Drawn out, as the spire of a shell.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Emarginate. Bluntly notched.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Encysted. Enclosed in a cyst.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Entocone. The inner cusp on the teeth of the radula.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Entire. With even, unbroken edges, as the aperture of some shells.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
[[Epiphallus]]. A portion of the vas deferens which becomes modified into a tube-like organ and is continued beyond the apex of the penis; it frequently bears a blind duct, or flagellum.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Epithelium. All tissues bounding a free surface.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Equidistant. Equally spaced, as the spiral lines on some snail shells.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Equilibrating. Balancing equally.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Eroded. Worn away, as the epidermis on some shells.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Erosive. Capable of erosion.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Excavated. Hollowed out, as the columella of some snails.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Excurrent. Referring to the siphon which carries out the waste matter of the body.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
[[Exoskeleton]]. The outer skeleton; all shells are exoskeletons.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Exserted. Brought out.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Expanded. Spread out, as the lip of some shells.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Falcate. Scythe-shaped.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Fasciculus. A little bundle.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Flagellate. Animals with a flagellum or lash.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Flexuous. Formed in a series of curves or turnings, as the columella in some shells.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Flocculent. Clinging together in bunches.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Fluviatile. Living in running streams.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Fusiform. Thick in the middle and tapering at each end.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Gelatinous. Like jelly, as the eggs of some mollusks.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Gibbous. Very much rounded, as the whorls in some snails.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Glandular. Like a gland.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Globose. Rounded.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Granulated. Covered with little grains.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Gravid. A female mollusk with ovaries distended with young.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Gregarious. Living in colonies.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Gular. Relating to the windpipe or palate. In mollusks, referring to the innermost part of the aperture.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
[[Habitat]]. Locality of a species.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Hasmolymph. Molluscan blood.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Heliciform. In form like ''[[Helix (gastropod)|Helix]]''.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Hemispherical. Half a sphere.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
[[Herbivorous]]. Subsisting upon vegetable food.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
[[Hermaphrodite]]. Having the sexes united in the same individual.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
[[Hibernation]]. The act of hibernating or going to sleep for the winter months.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Hirsute. Covered with hairs, as some snails.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Hispid. Same as hirsute.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Homologous. Having the same position or value, as the wing of a bird and of a bat.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Hyaline. Glassy.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Imperforate. Not perforated or umbilicated.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Impressed. Marked by a furrow, as the impressed spiral lines on some gastropod shells.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Incrassate. Thickened.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Incurved. Leaned or bent over, as the apex in some snails.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Indented. Notched.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Inflected. Turned in, as the teeth of some snails.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Inhalent. Same as incurrent.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Inoperculate. Without an operculum.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Intercostate. Between the ribs or ridges.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Invaginate. One part bending into another, as the tentacles of some land snails.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Invertible. Capable of being inverted, or drawn in, as the eye-peduncles of a land snail.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
[[Juvenile (organism)|Juvenile]].
Keeled. With a more or less sharp projection at the periphery.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Lamellated. Covered with scales.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Lamelliform. Having the form of scales.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Laminated. Consisting of plates or scales laid over each other.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Lanceolate. Gradually tapering to a point.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Lateral. Pertaining to the side.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Latticed. (See decussated.)<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Lobulate. Composed of lobes.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Longitudinal. The length of a shell.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Lunate. Shaped like a half moon, as the aperture in some shells.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Malleated. Appearing as though hammered.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Manducatory. Relating to the apparatus for masticating food. In snails, the jaws and radula.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Median. Middle, as the middle tooth on the radula.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Mesocene. The middle cusp on the teeth of the radula.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Monoecius. Having the sexes united in the same individual.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Multifid. Made up of many lobes or projections, as the cusps on some radulae.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Multispiral. Consisting of many whorls, as some fresh-water snails.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Nacreous. Pearly or iridescent.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Nepionic. The second stage of the embryonic shell, as the glochidium.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Notched. Nicked or indented, as the anterior canal of some gastropods.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Nucleus. The first part or beginning, as the apex in a gastropod shell.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Nucleated. Having a nucleus.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Obconic. In the form of a reversed cone.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Oblique. Slanting, as the aperture of some shells when not parallel to the longitudinal axis.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Obovate. Reversed ovate, as some shells when the diameter is greater near the upper than at the lower part.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Obtuse. Dull or blunt, as the apex of some gastropods.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Olfactory. Pertaining to the smell.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Olivaceous. Colored like an olive.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Organism. An organized being, or living object made up of organs.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Ovate. Egg-shaped.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Ovately conic. Shaped like an egg, but with a somewhat conic apex, as some gastropods.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Oviparous. Bringing forth young in an egg which is hatched after it is laid.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Ovisac. A pouch in which the eggs or embryos are contained.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Ovoviviparous. In this case the young are formed in an egg but are hatched inside the parent.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
[[Pallial lung]].
Papillose. Covered with many little bulgings or pimples.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Parallel. Having the same relative distance in all parts, as when the spiral lines in univalve shells are the same distance apart all the way around.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Patelliform. Shaped like a flattened-out cone, as an ''[[Ancylus]]''.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Patulous. Open and spreading, as the aperture in some gastropods.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Paucispiral. Only slightly spiral, as some opercula.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Pectinate. Like the teeth of a comb, as the gills of some mollusks.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Pedal. Pertaining to the foot.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Pedunculated. Supported on a stem or stalk, as the eyes of land snails.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Pellucid. Transparent or clear, as the shells of some snails; e. g. ''[[Vitrea]]''.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Penultimate. The whorl before the last in gastropod shells.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Pericardium. The chamber containing the heart.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
[[Periostracum]]. The epidermal covering of some shells.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Pervious. Very narrowly open, as the umbilicus in some snails.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Phytophagus. Vegetable-feeding.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Pilose. Covered with hairs.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Pinnate. Branched like a feather, as the gills of some mollusks.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Plaited. Folded.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
[[Planispiral]] shell.
Planorboid. Flat and orb-like, as some snails.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Pleurae. Relating to the side of a body.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Plexus. A network of vessels, as the form of the lungs in snails.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Plicated. Made up of folds.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Plumose. Resembling plumes.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Polygonal. Having many angles.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Porcellanous. Like porcelain.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Prismatic. Like a prism.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Prodissoconch. The embryonic shell.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
[[Protoconch]]. The embryonic shell.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Protract. To push out.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Protractor pedis. The foot protractor muscle.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Protrusile. Capable of being pushed out.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Proximal. The nearest end of an object.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Pulsation. A throb, as the throbbing of the heart.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Pupiform. Like a pupa; one of the stages in the development of an insect.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Pustulate. Covered with pustules or little pimples.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Pustulose. Same as pustulate.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Pyramidal. Having the form of a pyramid.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Pyriform. Shaped like a pear.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Reflected. Bent backward, as the lip in some snails.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Reflexed. Same as Reflected.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Renal. Relating to the kidneys.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Reticulated. Resembling a network, as when the longitudinal and spiral lines cross in a snail.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Retractile. Capable of being drawn in, as the eye peduncles in land snails.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Retractor pedis. Foot retractor muscle.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Revolving lines. Spiral lines on a snail shell which run parallel with the sutures.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Rhombic. Having four sides, the angles being oblique.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Rhomboid. Four-sided, but two of the sides being longer than the others.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Rimate. Provided with a very small hole or crack, as some snails in which the umbilicus is very narrowly open.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Roundly lunate. Rounder than lunate (which see).<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Rostriform. In the form of a rostrum.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Rudimentary. Not fully formed; imperfect.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Rugose. Rough or wrinkled, as parts of some shells.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Sacculated. Somewhat like a sac, or composed of sac-like parts.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Scalar. Resembling a ladder.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Secreted. Produced or deposited from the blood or glands, as the shell material in mollusks.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Semicircular. Half round or circular, as the aperture in some snails.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Semidentate. Half toothed, as the parietal wall in some land snails.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Semielliptic. Half elliptical.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Semiglobose. Half, or not quite globose.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Semilunate. Half lunate.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Semioval. Half, or not quite oval.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Serrated. Notched, like the teeth on a saw.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Serriform. In the form of series.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Sessile. Attached without a stem, as the eyes in some water snails.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Shouldered. Ridged, as the whorls in some snails.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Sigmoid. Shaped like the letter S.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Siliceous. Made up of silex.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Sinistral. Having the aperture on the left side.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Sinuous. Curved in and out, as the edge of some bivalves and the lips of some snails.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Spatulate. In the form of a spatula, a flat-bladed instrument used by druggists in pulverizing drugs.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Spherical. Shaped like a sphere.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Spiral. Wound about a central cavity, as the whorls of snails.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Striated. Marked by lines or striae.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Subangulated. Moderately angled.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Subcarinated. Moderately carinated.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Subcentral. Not quite in the center.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Subcircular. Not quite circular.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Subconical. Moderately conical.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
[[Subcylindrical]]. Moderately cylindrical.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Subequal. Not quite equal.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Subexcavated. A little excavated.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Subfusiform. Moderately fusiform.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Subglobose. Moderately globose.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Subglobular. Moderately globular.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Subhyaline. Moderately glassy.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Subimperforate. Not much perforated.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Suboblong. Moderately oblong.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Subobsolete. Almost disappearing.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Subovate. Nearly ovate.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Subparallel. Almost parallel.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Subperforated. Almost perforated.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Subquadrate. Almost four-sided.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Subreflected. Moderately turned back.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Subrotund. Moderately round.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Subspiral. Moderately spiral.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Subtriangulate. Moderately or almost triangular.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Subtrigonal. Moderately three-angled.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Subtruncate. Moderately cut off.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Subumbilicated. Moderately umbilicated.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Sulcated. Grooved.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Sulcus. A longitudinal furrow.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Superanal. Above the anus.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Supra-peripheral. Above the periphery.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Symmetrical. Alike on both sides or uniform in all parts.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Terrestrial. Living on the land.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Testaceous. Composed of shelly matter.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
[[Torsion (gastropod)|Torsion]]. A twisting around.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Tortuous. Twisted or winding.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Torpid. Half unconscious or asleep, as a snail during hibernation.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Translucent. Not quite transparent; light is seen through the thin edges of the object.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Transparent. Objects may be seen through the substance.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Transverse. Referring to the form of a shell when it is wider than high.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Tricuspidate. Having three cusps.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Trifid. Having three branches.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Trigonal. Having three angles.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Trilobate. Having three lobes.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Tripartite. Divided into three parts, as the foot of some snails.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Truncate. Having the end cut off squarely.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Tuberculate. Covered with tubercles or rounded knobs.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Turbinate. Having the form of a top.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Turriculated. Having the form of a tower.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Turreted. Having the form of a tower.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Umbilicated. Having an opening in the base of the shell.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Undulated. Having undulations or waves.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Univalve. Having the shell composed of a single piece, as a snail.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Varicose. Swollen or enlarged.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Vascular. Containing or made up of blood vessels.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Vermiform. Formed like a worm.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Ventral. The lower border or side.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Ventricose. Swollen or inflated on the ventral side.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Vibratile. Moving from side to side.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>
Vitreous. Resembling glass, as some snails.<ref name="Baker 1898"/>

C.]] (1898). [https://archive.org/details/molluscaofchicag02bakeiala ''The Mollusca of the Chicago area''], The Chicago Academy of Sciences, pages [https://archive.org/stream/molluscaofchicag02bakeiala#page/380/mode/2up 381]-390.</ref> }}

page.title: How I Killed Pluto and Why It Had It Coming

revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{Infobox book | name = How I Killed Pluto and Why It Had It Coming | image = How I Killed Pluto and Why It Had It Coming.jpg| image_size = | alt = | caption = | author = [[Michael E. Brown]] | audio_read_by = | title_working = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | subject = | genre = | publisher = | publisher2 = | pub_date = 2010 | published = | media_type = | pages = | awards = | isbn = 0-385-53108-7 | isbn_note = | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | wikisource = | notes = | exclude_cover = | website = }} '''''How I Killed Pluto and Why It Had It Coming''''' is the 2010 memoir by [[Michael E. Brown|Mike Brown]], the American [[astronomer]] most responsible for the [[2006 definition of planet|reclassification]] of the [[list of former planets|former]] planet [[Pluto]] from [[Definition of planet|planet]] to [[dwarf planet]].<ref name="Lengel2011"/><ref name="Brown-0-385-53108-7"/>
== Summary == The memoir is an account of the events surrounding the [[IAU definition of planet|redefinition of the term ''planet'']] that eventually changed the status of Pluto. It chronicles the discovery of [[Eris (dwarf planet)|Eris]], a dwarf planet then mistakenly thought to be larger than Pluto, located within the [[scattered disc]], beyond Neptune's orbit. The replaying of events includes the adversarial challenging of long-held scientific beliefs between some of the world's leading astronomers, and the eventual 2006 [[International Astronomical Union]]'s vote that removed Pluto from the list of [[Solar System]] planets.<ref name="Lengel2011"/>
== Reviews == Reviews of the book have been generally positive, with James Kennedy of ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' calling the book a "brisk" and "enjoyable ... chronicle" of the tale of the search for new planets and the eventual demotion of Pluto from planetary status.<ref name="Kennedy2010"/> Janet Maslin of the ''[[New York Times]]'' called it a "short, eager-to-please research memoir".<ref name="Maslin2010"/>
==See also== * [[List of former planets]]
== References == {{reflist | refs =
<ref name="Brown-0-385-53108-7"> {{cite book | title = How I Killed Pluto and Why It Had It Coming | first=Michael E. |last=Brown | date = 2010 | isbn = 0-385-53108-7 }} </ref>
<ref name="Lengel2011"> {{cite news | last = Lengel | first = Kerry | date = January 2, 2011 | publisher = [[The Arizona Republic]] | page = AE4 | accessdate = 2 January 2011 | url= http://www.azcentral.com/arizonarepublic/ae/articles/20110102republic-recommends-book-january-how-killed-pluto-why-had-coming-mike-brown.html | title= 'Republic' book pick for Jan.: 'How I Killed Pluto' }} </ref>
<ref name="Kennedy2010"> {{cite web | last = Kennedy | first = James | date = November 26, 2010 | title = The Man Who Made a Planet Vanish | work = Books and Ideas | publisher = [[The Wall Street Journal]] | url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704243904575630683559145518 | accessdate = 3 January 2011 }} </ref>
<ref name="Maslin2010"> {{cite web | last = Maslin | first = Janet | date = December 5, 2010 | title = Downsizing: When a Heavenly Body Got the Boot | work = Arts | publisher = [[The New York Times]] | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2010/12/06/books/06book.html | accessdate = 3 January 2011 }} </ref> }}

{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2016}} '''Human Proteinpedia''' is a portal for sharing and integration of human proteomic data.<ref>Kandasamy et al. Human Proteinpedia: a unified discovery resource for proteomics research. Nucleic Acids Research. Advance Access published on October 23, 2008, DOI 10.1093/nar/gkn701.</ref><ref>Mathivanan et al. Human Proteinpedia enables sharing of human protein data. Nat Biotechnology. 2008 Feb;26:164-7</ref> It allows research laboratories to contribute and maintain protein annotations. Human Protein Reference Database ([[HPRD]]) integrates data, that is deposited in Human Proteinpedia along with the existing literature curated information at the context of an individual protein.<ref>Mishra et al. Human protein reference database—2006 update. Nucleic Acids Res. 2006 Jan;34(Database issue):D411-4</ref><ref>Peri et al. Development of human protein reference database as an initial platform for approaching systems biology in humans. Genome Res. 2003 Oct;13:2363-71.</ref> In essence, researchers can add new data to HPRD by registering to Human Proteinpedia. The data deposited in Human Proteinpedia is freely available for download. Emphasizing the importance of [[proteomics]] data disposition to public repositories, ''Nature Methods'' recommends Human Proteinpedia in their editorial.<ref>Editorial. Thou shalt share your data. Nat Methods. 2008 Mar;5:209</ref> More than 70 labs participate in this effort.
==Data types==
Data pertaining to [[post-translational modifications]], [[protein–protein interactions]], tissue expression, expression in [[cell lines]], [[subcellular localization]] and [[enzyme]] substrate relationships can be submitted to Human Proteinpedia.
==Experimental platforms== Protein annotations present in Human Proteinpedia are derived from a number of platforms such as
# [[Co-immunoprecipitation]] and [[mass spectrometry]]-based protein–protein interaction # [[Co-immunoprecipitation]] and Western blotting based protein–protein interaction # [[Fluorescence]] based experiments # [[Immunohistochemistry]] # Mass spectrometric analysis # [[Protein]] and [[peptide microarray]]s # [[Western blot]]ting # [[Yeast two-hybrid]] based protein–protein interaction
This portal that allows adding of protein information was developed as a collaborative effort between the laboratory of Dr. Akhilesh Pandey at [[Johns Hopkins University]] and the [http://www.ibioinformatics.org Institute of Bioinformatics]
==FAQs== '''* What are the criteria for contributing data?'''
Any investigator who fulfills the following criteria can contribute data:
i) provides experimentally derived data, and,
ii) is willing to share data, and,
iii) is willing to be listed as the 'contributor' of the data
'''* Can I contribute data anonymously?'''
Anonymous contributions are not allowed. Contributor details should be clearly presented while contributing data.
'''* Can bioinformatically predicted data be shared through Human Proteinpedia?'''
Predictions of any type are not allowed. Contributed data should be derived experimentally and should be accompanied with experimental evidence.
'''* Is the contributed data subjected to peer review?'''
The data are not subjected to peer review and the actual experimental data (raw or processed) should be provided.
'''* What will happen to conflicting results from different laboratories?'''
In cases where a given entry is documented as erroneous, we will consult with the contributing group(s) about deleting the entry.
==External links== *[http://www.humanproteinpedia.org humanproteinpedia.org] *[http://www.hprd.org www.hprd.org]
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Bioinformatics]] [[Category:Proteomics]]

[[File:Amazonie deforestation.jpg|thumb|[[Deforestation]] (seen here in the Amazon) is a major driver of land change worldwide, and is often a subject of land change models.]] '''Land change models''' (LCMs) describe, project, and explain changes in and the dynamics of [[land use]] and [[Land cover|land-cover.]] LCMs are a means of understanding ways that humans are changing the Earth's surface in the past, present, in forecasting land change into the future.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Advancing Land Change Modeling: Opportunities and Research Requirements|last=Brown et al.|first=Daniel G.|publisher=The National Academic Press|year=2014|isbn=978-0-309-28833-0|location=Washington, DC|pages=1}}</ref>
Land change models are valuable in development policy, helping guide more appropriate decisions for [[Natural resource management|resource management]] and the [[natural environment]] at a variety of scales ranging from a small piece of land to the entire spatial extent.<ref name=":3">{{Cite book|title=Advancing Land Change Modeling: Opportunities and Research Requirements|last=Brown et al.|first=Daniel G.|publisher=The National Academic Press|year=2014|isbn=978-0-309-28833-0|location=Washington, DC|pages=11–12}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Brown|first=Daniel G|last2=Verburg|first2=Peter H|last3=Pontius Jr|first3=Robert Gilmore|last4=Lange|first4=Mark D|date=2013|title=Opportunities to improve impact, integration, and evaluation of land change models|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1877343513000912|journal=Current Opinion in Environmental Sustainability|volume=5|pages=452–457}}</ref> Moreover, developments within [[Land cover|land-cover]], environmental and [[Socioeconomics|socio-economic]] data (as well as within technological infrastructures) have increased opportunities for land change modeling to help support and influence decisions that affect [[Human-Environment interaction|human-environment systems]],<ref name=":3" /> as national and international attention increasingly focuses on issues of global [[climate change]] and [[sustainability]].
== Key concepts and other terminology == These are key concepts and various other terminologies necessary to understand the topic of land change modeling. {| class="wikitable sortable mw-collapsible" |+Figure 1.1: Key Concepts and Terminologies of Land Change Modeling !Concepts !Definitions !Concepts !Definitions |- |Pattern |a description of the change |[[Land use|Land Use]] |see link |- |Process |specific mechanisms that cause the change to happen |Projection |a representation of the future under a specific set of assumptions |- |[[Calibration]] |a procedure in which data is used to determine the parameters of the model<ref name=":4">{{Cite book|title=Advancing Land Change Modeling: Opportunities and Research Requirements|last=Brown et al.|first=Daniel G.|publisher=The National Academic Press|year=2014|isbn=978-0-309-28833-0|location=Washington, DC|pages=16–17}}</ref> |[[Forecasting]] |see link |- |[[Diagnosis]] |see link |[[Prediction]] |see link |- |Drivers |variables that affect land change outcomes<ref name=":4" /> |[[Scale (map)|Scale]] |see link |- |[[Equifinality]] |see link |Normative |the characteristic of being able to address questions of what should be |- |Multifinality |when a single process creates a variety of different patterns |Spatially Explicit Model |a model where a set of geographical locations is used for the specification of the data and output<ref name=":4" /> |- |Land Change |changes within the characteristics of a land surface, usually influenced by human action that alters environmental system conditions<ref name=":4" /> |Stationary |a phenomenon where a pattern or process of change is stable across space and time. While change can occur, it will be an even and stable amount of change across space and time. |- |[[Land cover|Land Cover]] |see link |Positive |the characteristic of being able to be rationally quantified, and being able to address questions of what is and what will be |- |[[Land systems|Land System]] |see link |n/a |n/a |}
== Importance of land change modeling == [[File:Spycharka DT 75.JPG|thumb|Bulldozers are often used to clear land for development or agriculture.]] Changes in [[land systems]] have consequences for climate and environmental change on every scale. Therefore, decisions and policies in relation to land systems are very important for reacting these changes and working towards a more sustainable society and planet.<ref name=":5">{{Cite book|title=Advancing Land Change Modeling: Opportunities and Research Requirements|last=Brown et al.|first=Daniel G.|publisher=The National Academic Press|year=2014|isbn=978-0-309-28833-0|location=Washington, DC|pages=13–14}}</ref>
Land change models are significant in their ability to help guide the land systems to positive societal and environmental outcomes at a time when attention to changes across land systems is increasing.<ref name=":5" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Briassoulis|first=Helen|date=2000-01-01|title=Analysis of Land Use Change: Theoretical and Modeling Approaches|url=http://econpapers.repec.org/bookchap/rriwholbk/17.htm}}</ref>
A plethora of science and practitioner communities have been able to advance the amount and quality of data in land change modeling in the past few decades. That has influenced the development of methods and technologies in model land change. The multitudes of land change models that have been developed are significant in their ability to address land system change and useful in various science and practitioner communities.<ref name=":5" />
For the science community, land change models are important in their ability to test theories and concepts of land change and its connections to human-environment relationships, as well as explore how these dynamics will change future land systems without real-world observation.<ref name=":5" />
Land change modeling is useful to explore spatial land systems, uses, and covers. Land change modeling can account for complexity within dynamics of land use and land cover by linking with climactic, ecological, biogeochemical, biogeophysical and socioeconomic models. Additionally, LCMs are able to produce spatially explicit outcomes according to the type and complexity within the land system dynamics within the spatial extent. Many biophysical and socioeconomic variables influence and produce a variety of outcomes in land change modeling.<ref name=":5" />
== Model uncertainty == [[File:Uriage Land Cover Change.png|thumb|300x300px|Land change is visible in this image from Japan. Models cannot be as certain as satellite imagery.]] A notable property of all land change models is that they have some irreducible level of uncertainty in the model structure, parameter values, and/or input data. For instance, one uncertainty within land change models is a result from [[wikt:temporal|temporal]] non-stationarity that exists in land change processes, so the further into the future the model is applied, the more uncertain it is.<ref name=":6">{{Cite book|title=Advancing Land Change Modeling: Opportunities and Research Requirements|last=Brown et al.|first=Daniel G.|publisher=The National Academic Press|year=2014|isbn=978-0-309-28833-0|location=Washington, DC|pages=21–22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Liu|first=XiaoHang|last2=Andersson|first2=Claes|date=2004-01-01|title=Assessing the impact of temporal dynamics on land-use change modeling|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0198971502000455|journal=Computers, Environment and Urban Systems|series=Geosimulation|volume=28|issue=1–2|pages=107–124|doi=10.1016/S0198-9715(02)00045-5}}</ref> Another uncertainty within land change models are data and [[parameter]] uncertainties within physical principles (i.e., surface typology), which leads to uncertainties in being able to understand and predict physical processes.<ref name=":6" />
Furthermore, land change model design are a product of both decision-making and physical processes. Human-induced impact on the socio-economic and ecological environment is important to take into account, as it is constantly changing land cover and sometimes model uncertainty. To avoid model uncertainty and interpret model outputs more accurately, a model diagnosis is used to understand more about the connections between land change models and the actual land system of the spatial extent. The overall importance of model diagnosis with model uncertainty issues is its ability to assess how interacting processes and the landscape are represented, as well as the uncertainty within the landscape and its processes.<ref name=":6" />
== Approaches to land change modeling ==
=== Machine learning & statistical models === A [[Machine learning|machine-learning approach]] uses land-cover data from the past to try to assess how land will change in the future, and works best with large datasets. There are multiple types of machine-learning and statistical models - a study in western Mexico from 2011 found that results from two outwardly similar models were considerably different, as one used a [[Artificial neural network|neural network]] and the other used a simple weights-of-evidence model.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pérez-Vega|first=Azucena|last2=Mas|first2=Jean-François|last3=Ligmann-Zielinska|first3=Arika|date=2012-03-01|title=Comparing two approaches to land use/cover change modeling and their implications for the assessment of biodiversity loss in a deciduous tropical forest|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S136481521100209X|journal=Environmental Modelling & Software|volume=29|issue=1|pages=11–23|doi=10.1016/j.envsoft.2011.09.011}}</ref>
=== Cellular models === A [[Cellular automaton|cellular]] land change model uses maps of suitability for various types of land use, and compares areas that are immediately adjacent to one another to project changes into the future. Variations in the scale of cells in a cellular model can have significant impacts on model outputs.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pan|first=Ying|last2=Roth|first2=Andreas|last3=Yu|first3=Zhenrong|last4=Doluschitz|first4=Reiner|date=2010-08-01|title=The impact of variation in scale on the behavior of a cellular automata used for land use change modeling|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0198971510000244|journal=Computers, Environment and Urban Systems|volume=34|issue=5|pages=400–408|doi=10.1016/j.compenvurbsys.2010.03.003}}</ref>
=== Sector-based & spatially disaggregated economic models === Economic models are built on principles of [[supply and demand]]. They use mathematical parameters in order to predict what land types will be desired and which will be discarded. These are frequently built for urban areas, such as a 2003 study of the highly dense [[Pearl River Delta]] in southern [[China]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Seto|first=Karen C.|last2=Kaufmann|first2=Robert K.|date=2003-02-01|title=Modeling the Drivers of Urban Land Use Change in the Pearl River Delta, China: Integrating Remote Sensing with Socioeconomic Data|url=http://le.uwpress.org/content/79/1/106|journal=Land Economics|language=en|volume=79|issue=1|pages=106–121|doi=10.2307/3147108|issn=0023-7639}}</ref>
=== Agent-based models === Agent-based models try to simulate the behavior of many individuals making independent choices, and then see how those choices affect the landscape as a whole. Agent-based modeling can be complex - for instance, a 2005 study combined an agent-based model with computer-based [[genetic programming]] to explore land change in the [[Yucatán Peninsula|Yucatan peninsula]] of Mexico.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Manson|first=Steven M.|date=2005-12-01|title=Agent-based modeling and genetic programming for modeling land change in the Southern Yucatán Peninsular Region of Mexico|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0167880905002422|journal=Agriculture, Ecosystems & Environment|volume=111|issue=1–4|pages=47–62|doi=10.1016/j.agee.2005.04.024}}</ref>
=== Hybrid approaches === Many models do not limit themselves to one of the approaches above - they may combine several in order to develop a fully comprehensive and accurate model.
== Implementation opportunities for land change modeling ==
Scientists use LCMs to build and test theories in land change modeling for a variety of human and environmental dynamics.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title=Advancing Land Change Modeling: Opportunities and Research Requirements|last=Brown et al.|first=Daniel|publisher=The National Academy of Sciences|year=2014|isbn=978-0-309-28833-0|location=500 Fifth Street, N.W. Washington, DC 20001|pages=13}}</ref> Land change modeling has a variety of implementation opportunities in many science and practice disciplines, such as in decision-making, policy, and in real-world application in public and private domains. The science disciplines use LCMs to formalize and test land change theory, and the explore and experiment with different scenarios of land change modeling. The practical disciplines use LCMs to analyze current land change trends and explore future outcomes from policies or actions in order to set appropriate guidelines, limits and principles for policy and action. Research and practitioner communities may study land change to address topics related to land-climate interactions, water quantity and quality, food and fiber production, and urbanization, infrastructure, and the built environment.<ref name=":2" />
== Improvement and advancement of land change modeling ==
=== Improved land observational strategies === [[File:Markham-suburbs aerial-edit2.jpg|thumb|Aerial photography can be used in conjunction with satellite imagery and ground data to improve land change models.]] One improvement for land change modeling can be made through better data and integration with available data and models. Improved observational data can influence modeling quality. Finer spatial and temporal resolution data that can integrate with [[Socioeconomics|socioeconomic]] and biogeophysical data can help land change modeling couple the socioeconomic and biogeological modeling types. Land change modelers should value data at finer scales. Fine data can give a better conceptual understanding of underlying constructs of the model and capture additional dimensions of land use. It is important to maintain the temporal and spatial continuity of data from airborne-based and survey-based observation through constellations of smaller satellite coverage, image processing algorithms, and other new data to link [[Satellite imagery|satellite-based]] land use information and land management information. It is also important to have better information on land change actors and their beliefs, preferences, and behaviors to improve the predictive ability of models and evaluate the consequences of alternative policies.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Brown et al.|first=Daniel|date=October 2013|title=Opportunities to improve impact, integration, and evaluation of land change models|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cosust.2013.07.012|journal=Current Opinion in Environmental Sustainability|volume=5|pages=452–457}}</ref>
=== Aligning model choices with model goals === One important improvement for land change modeling can be made though better aligning model choices with model goals. It is important to choose the appropriate modeling approach based on the scientific and application contexts of the specific study of interest. For example, when someone needs to design a model with policy and policy actors in mind, they may choose an agent-based model. Here, structural economic or agent-based approaches are useful, but specific patterns and trends in land change as with many ecological systems may not be as useful. When one needs to grasp the early stages of problem identification, and thus needs to understand the scientific patterns and trend of land change, machine learning and cellular approaches are useful.<ref name=":1" />
=== Integrating positive and normative approaches === Land Change Modeling should also better integrate positive and normative approaches to explanation and prediction based on evidence-based accounts of land systems. It should also integrate optimization approaches to explore the outcomes that are the most beneficial and the processes that might produce those outcomes.<ref name=":1" />
=== Integrating across scales === It is important to better integrate data across scales. A models design is based on the dominant processes and data from a specific scale of application and spatial extent. Cross-scale dynamics and feedbacks between temporal and spatial scales influences the patterns and processes of the model. Process like tele-coupling, indirect land use change, and adaption to climate change at multiple scales requires better representation by cross-scale dynamics. Implementing these processes will require a better understanding of feedback mechanisms across scales.<ref name=":0" />
=== Opportunities in research infrastructure and cyberinfrastructure support === As there is continuous reinvention of modeling environments, frameworks, and platforms, land change modeling can improve from better research infrastructure support. For example, model and [[Software development process|software infrastructure development]] can help avoid duplication of initiatives by land change modeling community members, co-learn about land change modeling, and integrate models to evaluate impacts of land change. Better data infrastructure can provide more data resources to support compilation, curation, and comparison of heterogeneous data sources. Better community modeling and governance can advance decision-making and modeling capabilities within a community with specific and achievable goals. Community modeling and [[Community government|governance]] would provide a step towards reaching community agreement on specific goals to move modeling and data capabilities forward.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Advancing Land Change Modeling: Opportunities and Research Requirements|last=Brown et al.|first=Daniel G|publisher=The National Academic Press|year=2014|isbn=978-0-309-28833-0|location=Washington, DC|pages=7–8}}</ref>
A number of modern challenges in land change modeling can potentially be addressed through contemporary advances in cyberinfrastructure such as crowd-source, “mining” for distributed data, and improving [[High Performance Computing|high-performance computing]]. Because it is important for modelers to find more data to better construct, calibrate, and validate structural models, the ability to analyze large amount of data on individual behaviors is helpful. For example, modelers can find point-of-sales data on individual purchases by consumers and internet activities that reveal social networks. However, some issues of privacy and propriety for crowdsourcing improvements have not yet been resolved.
The land change modeling community can also benefit from Global Positioning System and Internet-enabled mobile device data distribution. Combining various structural-based data-collecting methods can improve the availability of microdata and the diversity of people that see the findings and outcomes of land change modeling projects. For example, [[Crowdsourcing|citizen-contributed data]] supported the implementation of [[Ushahidi]] in [[Haiti]] after the [[2010 Haiti earthquake|2010 earthquake]], helping at least 4,000 disaster events. Universities, non-profit agencies, and volunteers are needed to collect information on events like this to make positive outcomes and improvements in land change modeling and land change modeling applications. Tools such as mobile devices are available to make it easier for participants to participate in collecting micro-data on agents. [[Google Maps]] uses cloud-based mapping technologies with datasets that are co-produced by the public and scientists. Examples in agriculture such as coffee farmers in Avaaj Otalo showed use of mobile phones for collecting information and as an interactive voice.
Cyberinfrastructure developments may also increase the ability of land change modeling to meet computational demands of various modeling approaches given increasing data volumes and certain expected model interactions. For example, improving the development of processors, data storage, network bandwidth, and coupling land change and environmental process models at high resolution.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Advancing Land Change Modeling: Opportunities and Research Requirements|last=Brown et al.|first=Daniel G.|publisher=The National Academic Press|year=2014|isbn=978-0-309-28833-0|location=Washington, DC|pages=90–98}}</ref>
=== Model evaluation === An additional way to improve land change modeling is through improvement of [[Evaluation|model evaluation]] approaches. Improvement in [[sensitivity analysis]] is needed to gain a better understand of the variation in model output in response to model elements like input data, model parameters, initial conditions, boundary conditions, and model structure. Improvement in [[Pattern recognition|pattern validation]] can help land change modelers make comparisons between model outputs parameterized for some historic case, like maps, and observations for that case. Improvement in uncertainty sources is needed to improve forecasting of future states that are non-stationary in processes, input variables, and boundary conditions. One can explicitly recognize stationarity assumptions and explore data for evidence in non-stationarity to better acknowledge and understand model uncertainty to improve uncertainty sources. Improvement in structural validation can help improve acknowledgement and understanding of the processes in the model and the processes operating in the real world through a combination of qualitative and quantitative measures.<ref name=":1" />
== See also == * [[GeoMod]] * [[Land use]] and [[Land-use planning|land use planning]] * [[Land-use forecasting]] * [[Land Use Evolution and Impact Assessment Model]] (LEAM) * [[TerrSet]]
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Scientific modeling]] [[Category:Land management]]

This a list of the best known [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] [[mathematician]]s. This list includes some [[Poland|Polish]], [[Russian Empire|pre-revolutionary Russian]] and [[USSR|Soviet]] mathematicians who lived or worked in [[Ukraine]].
__NOTOC__ {{compact ToC|side=yes|top=yes|num=yes}}

*[[Naum Akhiezer|Akhiezer, Naum Ilyich]] (1901–1980)
== B ==
* [[Sergei Natanovich Bernstein|Bernstein, Sergei Natanovich]] (1880–1968) * [[Valentina Borok|Borok, Valentina Mikhailovna]] (1931–2004) * [[Leonid Berlyand|Berlyand, Leonid Viktorovich]] (1957 -
== D ==
* [[Anatoliy Yakovlevich Dorogovtsev|Dorohovtsev, Anatoliy Yakovych]] (1935–2004) * [[Vladimir Drinfeld|Drinfeld, Volodymyr Gershonovych]] (b. 1954)

== K == * [[Mikhail Kadets|Kadets, Mikhail Iosiphovich]] (1923–2011) * [[Volodymyr Korolyuk|Korolyuk, Volodymyr Semenovych]] (b. 1925) * [[Igor N. Kovalenko|Kovalenko, Ihor Mykolayovych]] (b. 1935) * [[Kondratiev, Yuri]] (b. 1953) * [[Volodymyr Koshmanenko|Koshmanenko, Volodymyr Dmytrovych]] (b. 1943) * [[Mikhail Kravchuk|Kravchuk, Myhailo Pylypovych]] (1892, Volhynia–1942, Magadan oblast', USSR) * [[Mark Krein|Krein, Mark Grigorievich]] (1907–1989) * [[Nikolay Mitrofanovich Krylov|Krylov, Mykola Mytrofanovych]] (1879–1955)
== L == * [[Boris Levin|Levin, Boris Yakovlevich]] (1906–1993)
== M ==
* [[Vladimir Marchenko|Marchenko, Volodymyr Olexandrovych]] (b. 1922) * [[Vladimir Mikhalevich|Mikhalevich, Volodymyr Serhiyovych]] (1930–1994) * [[Yurii Mitropolskiy|Mitropolskiy, Yurii Oleksiyovych]] (1917–2008) * [[Maryna Viazovska]]

* [[Mark Naimark|Naimark, Mark Aronovich]] (1909–1978)

== S ==
* [[Anatoly Samoilenko|Samoilenko, Anatoliy Myhailovych]] (b. 1938) * [[Anatoliy Skorokhod|Skorokhod, Anatoliy Volodymyrovych]] (b. 1930) * [[Evgeni E. Slutsky|Slutskiy, Yevgeny Yevgenyevich]] (1880–1948) * [[Naum Z. Shor|Shor, Naum Zuselevevich]] (1937–2006)
== V == * [[Vladimir Drinfeld]] (1954), [[fields medal]] laureate. * [[Mikhail Vashchenko-Zakharchenko|Vaschenko-Zakharchenko, Myhailo Yegorovych]] (1825–1912) * [[Georgy Feodosevich Voronoy|Voronyi, Georgiy Feodosiyovych]] (1868–1908)
== Y ==
* [[Myhailo Yadrenko|Yadrenko Myhailo Yosypovych]] (1932–2004)
==Mathematicians born in Ukraine==
